results.title: Yang and yin: gender in Chinese cinema: a film to celebrate 100 years of cinema: by Stanley Kwan
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kwan, Creation Workshop, Media Asia Distribution and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Yan and Yin: gender in Chinese Cinema is a fascinating insight into Chinese films. In this context ‘Chinese’ incorporates films from Hong Kong and Tawain as well as mainland China. Kwan’s documentary is a highly personal view which looks in particular at subtextual issues of homosexuality and transexuality in Chinese films. The film includes interviews with John Woo, Ang Lee, Hou Hsiao Hsien, Leslie Cheung, Chen Kaige and Chang Cheh, who was an integral director in the Shaw Brothers martial arts films from which Bruce Lee emerged. There are also countless excerpts from films which span the century, including early Chinese cinema and Cantonese Opera Films featuring Yan Kin-Fai and Baak Suet-Sin, a famous lesbian couple who were extremely popular in the fifties. There are also excerpts from “Way of the Dragon” (Bruce Lee), John Woo’s “A Better Tomorrow” and “The Killer”, Wong Kar-Wai’s “Fallen Angels” (309301) and “Ashes of Time” (309077), Chen Kaige’s “Farewell My Concubine” (306547) and “The Big Red”, Xie Jin’s “Hibiscus Town”, Ang Lee’s “The Wedding Banquet” (306767) and Hou Hsiao Hsien’s “A City of Sadness”. With photography by Chris Doyle and narration read by Tony Rayns. In English, Cantonese and Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Century of cinema. Volume 1 (UK, Ireland, Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
White fellas dreaming. Written and directed by George Miller. Produced by George Miller and Doug Mitchell. 1996. Miller presents an entertaining journey through Australian cinema. Cinema is discussed in relation to the changing nature of society and how Australians have constructed and deconstructed a national cinema through celluloid. A must see for anyone interested in Australian cinema heritage. “Cinema of unease. A personal journey by Sam Neill”. Written and directed by Sam Neill and Judy Rymer. Produced by Paula Jalfon and Grant Campbell. 1995. New Zealand cinema is a recent addition to the realm of national cinema, experiencing a significant growth in the previous two decades. Neill visits the land he migrated to and his experience as a performer and a viewer. “Typically British”. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Frears explores the notion of the incompatibility of ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ in a personal way to present the outstanding films and film-makers of Britain.

results.title: 2 x 50 Years of French cinema: night of the filmmakers: I am curious, film
results.creator_credit: Stig Bjorkman, Edgar Reitz, Jean-Luc Godard, Anne-Marie Mieville, Lennart Dunner, Robert Busch, Channel Four and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
2x50 years of French cinema (52 mins, 1995) ‘Why celebrate cinema? Isn’t it famous already?’: Jean-Luc Godard confronts actor Michel Piccoli, president of France’s First Century of Cinema Association with his theory that French cinema has been forgotten, that he and Mieville are making a film about a century of French cinema that will be a chronicle of forgetting. Piccoli puts this theory to the test with the staff of the hotel where he is staying and is dismayed to find barely any recognition of names from French film history or even classic movies such as ‘La regle du jeu’. Set in Munich, in a magnificent new Kinemathek opened to celebrate the first century of cinema, ‘Night of the Filmmakers’ (54 mins, 1994) imagines an assembly of German filmmakers such that only the artifice of film could bring together, attempting to find answers to questions such as, what exactly makes a German film German? How much was lost to German cinema with all the talent fleeing the Nazi regime? What was the effect on film-making on the Berlin Wall? Includes interviews with Volker Schlondorff, Helma Sanders-Brahms, Werner Herzog, Wim Wenders, Frank Beyer and Wolfgang Kohlhasse. Actress Hanna Schygulla reminisces about Rainer Werner Fassbinder. In ‘I am curious, film’ (52 mins, 1995) actress Lena Nyman is Bjoerkman’s guide on a journey through Nordic cinema history, attempting to discover the special elements of Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Finnish and Icelandic cinema. Her journey is richly illustrated with film clips and includes conversations with filmmakers such as Lars von Trier, Stefan Jarl, Liv Ullman and Aki Kaurismaki. In French, German, Danish with English subtitles - some sections in English.
results.title_for_label: 2 x 50 Years of French cinema: night of the filmmakers: I am curious, film

results.title: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Nagisa Oshima, Park Ki-Yong, Eiko Oshima and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
‘Nagisa Oshima’s 100 Years of Japanese Cinema’ is a fascinating personal journey through the history of Japanese film-making which moves from the end of the 19th century through to the mid-90s. A rare chance to see stills and excerpts from classic films made in Japan. Oshima comments on his own films as well as the Japanese film industry and its relationship to the country’s political and social changes. Films by great Japanese directors from Muzoguchi, Ozu, Kurosawa, ‘Beat’ Takeshi Kitano, Manga films and Japanese documentary makers are all discussed. ‘The Cinema On The Road’ is a wonderful documentary which uses the road movie genre as a device to explore the history and current contexts of Korean Cinema. With interesting footage of the Korean landscape and cities, as well as interviews with directors and excerpts and stills from films, this is a fascinating insight into a national cinema which is rarely seen. Both documentaries are in English with interviews and film excerpts in Japanese and Korean with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea

results.title: The Century of cinema
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: ‘The Century of cinema’ is a series of highly personal documentaries made by leading film directors throughout the world. It was executive produced by Colin MacCabe and Bob Last for BFI TV and Channel Four Television in association with a world-wide alliance of broadcasters and distributors.

results.title: Typically British: Irish cinema: ourselves alone?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Typically British. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Francois Truffaut once observed that the words ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ seemed incompatable. In his celebration of 100 years of British Cinema, Stephen Frears shapes an elegant and witty riposte to this statement. In discussion with other British film-makers, Frears explores the wealth of stylish and familiar images created by the British film industry over the last century. “Irish Cinema: Ourselves alone”. Produced and directed by Donald Taylor Black. Narrated by Gabriel Byrne, this documentary looks at the struggle of Irish people to create an Irish cinema. Carefully intercutting interviews with directors, writers and producers with clips from feature films, location footage and fascinating archive material, Donald Taylor Black compares past and present in order to ask questions about the future of Irish cinema.

results.title: The Celts
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Opus Television and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe. Using paintings, historical locations, buildings and re-enactments, this very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Opus Television and SBS-TV

Narrated by John Morgan.

results.title: A Dead song? [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Celts”.
The final episode in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. The Celts over the centuries have suffered many forms of identity crisis, be it religious, cultural, or lingual and this program explores, in particular, the near death of the Celtic languages during the 18th century through to the early 20th century. It would appear one of the major influencing factors behind the disappearing dialects occurred as each Celtic nation (Ireland, Scotland and Wales) came under English rule in the name of a United Kingdom. However, as history tells, these three nations certainly did not choose English rule voluntarily - it was forced upon them. The program discusses the various uprisings that took place including the Battle of Culloden (Scotland 1745), the Great Potato Famine (Ireland 1846) and the Easter Uprising (Ireland 1916). Also examines about the Industrial Revolution and its effect on the Welsh population where speaking Welsh was banned in schools and a concerted attempt was made by the ruling English to obliterate and decimate everything Welsh, including their culture and language. Today it is a different story as the Celts begin to reassert themselves as independent nations - Ireland in 1922, Scotland in 1998 and Wales heading there. Each nation has its own Celtic language television channel and through the means of mass media, the Celtic language and culture is being revived and perhaps redefined as the current generation explore their identity as a Celt but also as part of a global population. Using re-enactments, archival footage, stills and prints, this very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: Legend and reality [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Celts”.
The fifth in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. Using paintings, historical locations, buildings and re-enactments, this episode spans the 8th century through to the 17th century, recounting the wars, invasions, and the blood spilt in the name of the Church and a “United Kingdom”. The story begins with the Viking invasion in 793 AD on the Holy Isle of Lindisfarne where the complex web of Celtic Churches were savagely attacked and destroyed. This invasion, occupation and settlement, continued on through the years to 1066 and the Battle of Hastings when William, Duke of Normandy, defeated Harold II, and took the English throne heralding the beginning of a mass takeover by the Normans. Over time, the Celtic culture was almost absorbed and reality and truth lost its way as in the legend of King Arthur - the myth lives on even today. The continual assault on the Celtic communities by the English led to turmoil and revolt during the 1300s, with Scotland seemingly the only one to retain its independence through the emergence of William Wallace and then Robert Bruce. By 1532 AD, Brittany was defeated and absorbed into France, and in 1536 Wales became part of England. Under the reign of Elizabeth I (1550-1600 AD), Ireland fell fully under English rule and so began the “Irish problem”. From 1608 onwards, “plantations” began in Ireland whereby Protestant English and Scottish were encouraged to settle in Ireland and try and rid Ireland of its Catholic population. This very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: From Camelot to Christ [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Celts”.
The fourth in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. This program focuses on the Dark Ages, a time of the collapse of the Roman Empire in Britain and the impact this had on the future of the Celtic kingdoms is discussed. The removal of Roman authority in the north left the way open for fierce battles over dominant power in the Celtic kingdom. At this time the battle between the Saxons and the British began, with the ultimate success of the Saxons over the Celtic world despite the efforts of the Celtic heroes, rendered in Celtic folklore for the respite they brought for the British before the ultimate failure of their attempts to hold onto independence. One of the great figures to emerge from this time was Arthur, said to have halted the Saxon advance until the onset of the bubonic plague and the resulting disastrous effects on the British population which allowed the Saxons to conquer once again. At the same time the emergence of Christianity in Ireland is investigated in the program, with a discussion of the establishment of a veneer of the Roman Church over the already existing religious beliefs in the Celtic world and the eventual ruin of the true Celtic Church this caused.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
